clinical_study.brief_title: Association Between Clinical Signs and MRI Findings of the Lumbar Facet Joints
clinical_study.official_title: Association Between Clinical Signs Assessed by Manual Segmental Examination and Findings of the Lumbar Facet Joints in Magnetic-resonance Scans in Subjects With and Without Current Low Back - a Prospective Single-blinded Study

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine
1. the prevalence of lumbar facet joint pain detected by manual segmental provocation tests
2. the prevalence of MRI findings of the lumbar facet joints (hypertrophy, effusion, edema)
3. the association of lumbar facet joint pain and MRI findings on a segmental level
in subjects with current low back pain and in a control group.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of facet joints per person which show facet joint pain and FJ effusion and/ or edema
primary_outcome.description: association of facet joint pain and MRI facet joint findings is determined

secondary_outcome.measure: number of painful facet joints per person
secondary_outcome.description: prevalence of facet joint pain assessed by manual segmental provocation tests

secondary_outcome.measure: number of facet joints diagnosed with facet joint effusion and/ or edema per person
secondary_outcome.description: prevalence of facet joint findings in the lumbar spine assessed by MRI (facet joint effusion and/ or facet joint edema)

arm_group.description: subjects with current low back pain (i.e. more than 30 days of low back pain in the last three months)
subjects with less than 30 days of low back pain in the last three months

intervention.intervention_name: manual segmental examination of the lumbar facet joints
intervention.description: use of three different segmental facet joint provocation tests (spinal palpation, segmental rotation and springing-test) from Th12-L1 to L5-S1

study_pop.textblock: pain clinic, sports clubs and fitness centers

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for both study groups:
- age > 18
- written informed consent
- ability to perform required examinations
Inclusion Criterion for current low back pain-group:
- more than (>=) 30 days of low back pain in the last three months
Inclusion Criterion for control group:
- less than 30 days of low back pain in the last three months
Exclusion Criteria for both study groups:
- acute radicular low back pain in the last three months
- claustrophobia
- spondylodesis of the lumbar spine
- any metallic implants which are not MRI-compatible
